qas.question: Where did the BBC continue broadcasting from in October of 1936?
What frequency band was used by the BBC starting in 1936?
How many lines did the Baird transmission contain?
How many lines did the Marconi-EMI transmission contain?
On what days did the BBC provide regular broadcasts?
What housed scenery offices and make-up stores?
On what schedule were the 405-line Baird system and the 240-line Marconi system used?
What type of service was broadcast from 15:00 to 21:00?
What was broadcasting on the VFH band?

context: After a series of test transmissions and special broadcasts that began in August, <b5_0>regular BBC television broadcasts<b5_0/> officially resumed on 1 October 1936, from a converted wing of <a0_0><b6_0>Alexandra Palace<b6_0/><a0_0/> in London, which housed two studios, various scenery stores, make-up areas, dressing rooms, offices, and <b9_0>the transmitter<b9_0/> itself, now broadcasting on the <a1_0>VHF<a1_0/> band. BBC television initially used two systems, <b7_0>on alternate weeks<b7_0/>: the <a2_0>240<a2_0/>-line Baird intermediate film system and the <a3_0>405<a3_0/>-line Marconi-EMI system, each making the BBC the world's first regular <b8_0>high-definition<b8_0/> television service, broadcasting <a4_0>Monday to Saturday<a4_0/> from 15:00 to 16:00 and 21:00 to 22:00.
